user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketShutdown_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, OS_SocketShutdownMode_t Mode)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *conn_impl;
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             how;

    conn_impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /* Note that when called via the shared layer,
     * the "Mode" arg has already been checked/validated. */
    if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_READ)
    {
        how = SHUT_RD;
    }
    else if (Mode == OS_SocketShutdownMode_SHUT_WRITE)
    {
        how = SHUT_WR;
    }
    else
    {
        how = SHUT_RDWR;
    }

    if (shutdown(conn_impl->fd, how) == 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_SocketShutdown_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The macro takes the address of the token expression and passes it to OS_ObjectIndexFromToken which accepts a const OS_object_token_t *; the conversion from non-const to const is allowed. The pointer produced by the macro (&tbl[index]) is a pointer to the mutable table element intentionally (the table is declared non-const and may be modified elsewhere), so qualifying it const would not be appropriate here. (A violation would only exist if the table elements are never modified and could/should be declared const but are not.)
